images.copyright: Golden Bridge, Bà Nà Hills, Da Nang, Vietnam (© Hien Phung Thu/Shutterstock)
images.title: A walk among the clouds
images.caption: Golden Bridge, Bà Nà Hills, Da Nang, Vietnam
images.desc: Two colossal stone hands cradle a shimmering, golden walkway, as though the mountains themselves are offering it to the sky. Unlike conventional bridges, the Golden Bridge doesn't span a river or lake. Instead, it stretches across lush landscapes, connecting two cable car stations—Marseille Station and Bordeaux Station in Thien Thai Garden. Made from reinforced concrete and framed by hands crafted from steel mesh and fibreglass, the bridge creates an image of timeless strength amid modern ingenuity. Suspended around 950 metres above sea level, the walkway offers visitors a panoramic view of the verdant countryside. A symbol of Vietnam's creativity and natural beauty, the Golden Bridge invites you to experience a stroll like no other.

images.copyright: Ribblehead Viaduct and Ingleborough mountain, North Yorkshire, England, United Kingdom (© AWL Images/DanitaDelimont.com)
images.title: Bridging history, one arch at a time
images.caption: Ribblehead Viaduct, North Yorkshire, England
images.desc: Part engineering genius, part daredevil stunt—that's the Ribblehead Viaduct in North Yorkshire, England. This Victorian structure, also known as Batty Moss Viaduct, has been carrying trains and turning heads since the 1870s. Built by the Midland Railway, it's the longest and third-tallest on the Settle–Carlisle railway line. Stretching across the Ribble Valley, its 24 stone arches reach a height of 31 metres.
images.bsTitle: Bridging history, one arch at a time

images.title: Azure highlights
images.caption: Alappuzha, Kerala
images.desc: Tucked away in the state of Kerala, Alappuzha offers stunning backwater views, rustic village vibes and unforgettable sunsets. The city's landscape is mostly flat, with no major mountains or hills, though there are a few small hillocks scattered between the Bharanikkavu and Chengannur blocks in the eastern part. The area is also free from forests. This city holds a special place in the state's cultural calendar as a key site for the annual Nehru Trophy Boat Race, which takes place during Onam. On the western side, Alappuzha is bordered by the Laccadive Sea, and the town is crisscrossed by an intricate network of lakes, lagoons and freshwater rivers.

images.copyright: European beech forest in Belgium (© Philippe Moes/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Ageing gracefully
images.caption: European beech forest, Belgium
images.desc: Beech trees are pretty amazing. There are several species worldwide, but the European beech steals the spotlight in much of Europe. With its smooth grey bark, short trunk and sweeping branches, this tree is a standout in Belgium's forests, as shown in today's image. It grows in temperate regions and prefers well-drained, fertile soils, taking up to 30 years to mature. Not only do these 48-metre-tall trees dominate the landscape, but their wood is also used to make some of the sturdiest furniture, flooring and even kitchen tools.

images.copyright: Plains zebras at sunrise, Mokala National Park, South Africa (© EcoPrint/Shutterstock)
images.title: Anything but plain
images.caption: Happy International Zebra Day!
images.desc: Celebrate the beauty of zebras on International Zebra Day! These striking animals, known for their unique black and white patterns, are mostly found in the African savannah, stretching from Kenya to South Africa. Of the three zebra species—Grévy's zebra, plains zebra and mountain zebra—the Grévy's zebra is the most endangered, with more than half its population lost in only three decades. While plains zebras are thriving, mountain zebras face significant threats, such as poaching and habitat encroachment. Zebras play an essential role in the ecosystems they live in, coexisting with predators like lions and hyenas while shaping the grasslands they call home.

images.copyright: Roland's Breach, Ordesa y Monte Perdido National Park, Spain (© Inaki Relanzon/Nature Picture Library/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: Once more unto the breach
images.caption: Roland's Breach, Spain
images.copyrightonly: © Inaki Relanzon/Nature Picture Library/Alamy Stock Photo
images.desc: High up in the Pyrenees, there is a gap in the mountains. More than 90 metres tall and 39 metres wide, Roland's Breach, featured here today, is a sight to behold. But who was Roland? Count Roland was a Frankish military leader during Charlemagne's reign in the 8th century. Legend has it that, after being defeated in battle, Roland cut a gap in the mountains—either to destroy his sword or to catch one last glimpse of France.

images.copyright: Dragon dance, Wuhan, China (© Miao Jian/Wuhan Morning Post/Visual China Group via Getty Images)
images.title: Happy Chinese New Year!
images.caption: Chinese New Year
images.copyrightonly: © Miao Jian/Wuhan Morning Post/Visual China Group via Getty Images
images.desc: The streets come alive today with a symphony of firecrackers, red lanterns and cheerful chatter—it's Chinese New Year. Steeped in thousands of years of tradition, this holiday marks the start of the lunisolar Chinese calendar. One of the most captivating images associated with this festival is the dragon dance, pictured here. This is a mesmerising performance where skilled dancers manipulate a long, flexible dragon puppet, bringing it to life with sinuous, undulating movements. The dragon, a symbol of power, dignity and good fortune, is believed to bring luck to the community, with longer dragons bringing even more prosperity.

images.copyright: Short-eared owl hunting in heavy snow (© Dilshan Muthalib/Getty Images)
images.title: Snow-way you'll miss it
images.caption: Short-eared owl
images.desc: The short-eared owl, featured in today's image, is a grassland-dwelling member of the owl family. Found on all continents except Antarctica and Australia, it's one of the most widely distributed bird species. In India, it can be spotted in the open grasslands and vast stretches of the Little Rann of Kutch, as well as the surrounding desert landscape. This raptor belongs to the genus Asio, whose members are characterised by feather tufts ('ears') on their heads. The short-eared owl only reveals its tufts when feeling defensive.
